questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of yellow discoloration, dark urine, and itchiness. She does not have diarrhea but says her stools “look pale.” She has also had a fever and severe fatigue. She reports having symptoms of the stomach flu a week ago, which resolved with over-the-counter medication. She has no personal history of serious illness. She does not smoke and drinks an average of two beers on weekends. She does not use illicit drugs. She has been sexually active with the same partner for 12 years and uses condoms consistently. She works as a flight attendant for an international airline. She appears ill. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 64/min, and blood pressure is 132/82 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus, excoriation marks over her extremities, and parched lips. The liver is tender on palpation; there is no splenomegaly. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
10,300/mm3



Platelet count
256,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
19 mm/h


Prothrombin time
13 seconds


Serum



 Urea nitrogen
28 mg/dL


 Glucose
89 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.7 mg/dL


 Bilirubin, total
8 mg/dL


 Direct
4 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase
123 U/L


 AST
782 U/L


 ALT
1069 U/L


An ultrasound of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are highly suggestive of primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC), which typically affects women aged 35–60 years and manifests with fatigue, pruritus, jaundice, tender hepatomegaly, and dark urine with pale stools. However, while laboratory studies may show elevated conjugated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase in PBC, transaminases are typically within normal limits.

B) INCORRECT:

Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCAs) can be found in several autoimmune diseases, including primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). Patients with PSC are often asymptomatic but may develop signs and symptoms of cholestasis. However, transaminases are usually within normal limits or slightly elevated (< 300 U/L) in PSC. In addition, approximately 90% of patients with PSC have concomitant inflammatory bowel disease.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has acute viral hepatitis, most likely caused by the hepatitis A virus (HAV). The virus is transmitted through the fecal-oral route, usually as a result of ingestion of undercooked contaminated food (especially raw shellfish). HAV is endemic to tropical and subtropical regions, which the patient may have visited through her job as a flight attendant. After an incubation period of 2–6 weeks, patients develop a prodrome of fever, nausea, vomiting, and tender hepatomegaly (weeks 1–2), which typically resolves with the onset of the icteric phase, characterized by signs and symptoms of cholestasis (week 2). The presence of anti-HAV IgM antibodies, which usually develop within 5–10 days of exposure and are the first immunoglobulins produced by the immune system in response to the HAV, confirms the diagnosis of an active HAV infection. Anti-HAV IgG antibodies usually develop 2–3 weeks after the start of an active infection and persist indefinitely. HAV infection is generally self-limited and most patients only require supportive care.

D) INCORRECT:

Detection of anti-HEV IgG antibodies indicates a past hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection. In general, IgG immunoglobulins are not the first antibodies produced by the immune system in response to an acute infection, and in HEV infections, they reach their peak 4 weeks after initial infection. This patient likely developed an acute hepatitis infection one week ago, making the detection of anti-HEV IgG antibodies unlikely at this stage. Additionally, hepatitis E is less common than other types of viral hepatitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Detection of anti-HAV IgG antibodies indicates a former infection with or a past vaccination against hepatitis A. In general, IgG immunoglobulins are not the first antibodies produced by the immune system in response to acute infections and only appear 2–3 weeks after the initial infection. This patient's presentation is consistent with an acute hepatitis A infection that developed one week ago, making the detection of anti-HAV IgG antibodies unlikely at this stage.

F) INCORRECT:

HBsAg is a surface antigen of the hepatitis B virus (HBV) that indicates active hepatitis B infection. Patients with an acute hepatitis B infection may present with acute hepatitis similarly to this case, but it is often subclinical. In many cases, infection persists and leads to chronic hepatitis years later. HBV may be transmitted sexually, parenterally (e.g., needlestick injury), or perinatally. This patient does not have risk factors (e.g., multiple sex partners, exposure to HBV-infected persons, or IV drug use) for any of these modes of transmission, making hepatitis B an unlikely diagnosis.
questions.hint: Tender hepatomegaly with signs and symptoms of cholestasis (jaundice, dark urine, pale stools, pruritus, direct hyperbilirubinemia, elevated transaminases and alkaline phosphatase), preceded by fever, nausea, and vomiting, suggest a specific type of acute hepatitis.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has no history of serious illness. His mother has hypertension and his father died of testicular cancer at the age of 51 years. He does not smoke or drink. He is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. He takes no medications. His immunization records are unavailable. He works as a financial consultant and will go on a business trip to Mexico City in 6 weeks. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.7°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 122/78 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.4 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9800/mm3



Platelet count
168,000/mm3



Serum



 Glucose
93 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malaria chemoprophylaxis consists of the preventive administration of certain drugs (e.g., atovaquone-proguanil, mefloquine). Currently, the risk of malaria for US travelers to Mexico is very low. Mexico City is considered malaria-free. Therefore, the CDC does not routinely recommend the use of antimalarial drugs for individuals traveling to Mexico except for travelers going to the very South or some states near the Pacific coast.

B) INCORRECT:

Vaccination against rabies is indicated after exposure with a presumably infected animal (e.g., dog, bat) or for individuals who are at high risk of exposure, which include veterinarians and laboratory workers working with the rabies virus. International travelers to countries where the disease is endemic or where there is a low availability of vaccines (e.g., countries in Africa, South America, Southeast Asia, remote locations) should also receive the vaccine. This patient is going on a business trip, so he will not be in any remote locations for a long period of time.

C) INCORRECT:

As of 2017, a live oral cholera vaccine has been approved by the FDA. Vaccination against vibrio cholerae is indicated in travelers going to countries in which cholera infections are reported regularly or where a cholera outbreak is occurring. Although there has been a cholera epidemic in Mexico in the past, the risk for this business traveler is very low as long as he follows simple preventative measures (water and food hygiene).

D) INCORRECT:

Immunization against yellow fever is recommended for international travelers ≥ 9 months of age who plan on visiting endemic regions in South America or Sub-Saharan Africa. Because the disease is not prevalent in Mexico, this recommendation does not apply to this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Areas with moderate to high prevalence of hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection include most parts of South America, Africa, Asia, Eastern Europe, Mexico, and Central America. Travelers to these areas should receive an HAV vaccine (ideally ≥ 2 weeks before traveling). Individuals who are due to travel to these areas in < 2 weeks require both an HAV vaccine and immune globulin, which should be injected at different anatomical sites at the same time. Because HAV is transmitted mainly via the consumption of food or water that has been contaminated with feces (e.g., shellfish), travelers should also be advised to follow primary preventive measures such as washing hands, boiling or chlorinating water, and avoiding raw food.

As of 2006, routine immunization against HAV is recommended for all children in the US older than 12 months.
questions.hint: Considering that this patient's immunization records are unavailable and he will soon travel to Mexico, he needs to be vaccinated against several common illnesses.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for a 1-week history of jaundice and nausea. She recalls eating some seafood last weekend at a cookout. She lives at home with her 4-year-old son who attends a daycare center. The child's immunizations are up-to-date. The patient's temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 134/84 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. The liver is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin and is tender. Her serum studies show:


Total bilirubin
3.4 mg/dL


Alkaline phosphatase
119 U/L


AST
185 U/L


ALT
723 U/L


Hepatitis A IgM antibody
positive


Hepatitis B surface antibody
positive


Hepatitis B surface antigen
negative


Hepatitis B core IgM antibody
negative


Hepatitis C antibody
negative


Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate for this patient's child at this time?

choices.text: Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin and hepatitis B vaccine
Administer hepatitis A vaccine and hepatitis A immunoglobulin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Initial administration of hepatitis B vaccine only is part of the post-exposure prophylaxis in patients with a potential percutaneous or sexual exposure to hepatitis B who were previously immunized, but whose response to immunization is unknown. While hepatitis B infection can present with nausea, jaundice, hyperbilirubinemia, and transaminitis, this patient has confirmed HBV immunity (surface antigen and anti-core antibody negative, anti-surface antigen positive). Instead, her positive hepatitis A IgM antibody indicates acute hepatitis A infection. Additionally, her son has no history of exposure to bodily fluids from the mother, so he is not at risk of HBV infection regardless. Furthermore, the 4-year-old child has already received all age-appropriate vaccines, which includes the hepatitis B vaccine.

B) INCORRECT:

Administration of both hepatitis B immunoglobulin and vaccine is the preferred post-exposure prophylaxis for unvaccinated individuals or patients who have been incompletely immunized. While hepatitis B infection can present with nausea, jaundice, hyperbilirubinemia, and transaminitis, this patient has confirmed HBV immunity (surface antigen and anti-core antibody negative, anti-surface antigen positive). Instead, her positive hepatitis A IgM antibody indicates acute hepatitis A infection. Additionally, her son has no history of exposure to bodily fluids from the mother, so he is not at risk of HBV infection regardless. Furthermore, the 4-year-old child has already received all age-appropriate vaccines, which includes the hepatitis B vaccine.

C) INCORRECT:

HAV immunoglobulin alone is indicated as postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) in unvaccinated infants < 12 months old as well as individuals in whom HAV vaccination is contraindicated. Since the child is already vaccinated against hepatitis A, passive vaccination is not indicated. This 4-year-old child's vaccinations, including the HAV vaccine, are up to date, and thus, no PEP is indicated at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Isolation is not recommended when hepatitis A is diagnosed. Also, this child is vaccinated and unlikely to be infected and thus unlikely to infect others. Since hepatitis A is spread by the fecal-oral route, good hygiene (especially hand washing) is routinely recommended.

E) CORRECT:

According to the CDC, routine vaccination against HAV, which consists of a series of two shots (with the second being administered 6–18 months after the first), is recommended for all children > 12 months of age in the US. Because this child's immunizations are up-to-date (including the HAV vaccine), he does not require postexposure prophylaxis. Current guidelines do not recommend HAV booster vaccination after successful primary immunization, as it confers long-term immunity.

F) INCORRECT:

HAV vaccine is indicated as postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) in previously unvaccinated children ≥ 12 months of age and adults who are immunocompetent and have no history of chronic liver disease. Because this 4-year-old child's vaccinations (including the HAV vaccine) are up to date, PEP is not indicated at this time.

G) INCORRECT:

Administration of hepatitis B immunoglobulin is part of the post-exposure prophylaxis for unvaccinated individuals or patients who have been incompletely immunized. However, administration of hepatitis B immunoglobulin alone is an incomplete regimen as it only provides passive immunity. While hepatitis B infection can present with nausea, jaundice, hyperbilirubinemia, and transaminitis, this patient has confirmed HBV immunity (surface antigen and anti-core antibody negative, anti-surface antigen positive). Instead, her positive hepatitis A IgM antibody indicates acute hepatitis A infection. Additionally, her son has no history of exposure to bodily fluids from the mother, so he is not at risk of HBV infection regardless.

H) INCORRECT:

The combination of the HAV vaccine and immunoglobulin is indicated as postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) in HAV-exposed children ≥ 12 months and adults who are immunocompromised, have chronic liver disease, or have not been previously vaccinated. This 4-year-old child's vaccinations, including the HAV vaccine, are up to date, and therefore, no PEP is indicated at this time.
questions.hint: The patient has jaundice, fever, nausea, a history of eating seafood, and positive hepatitis A IgM antibodies all indicating acute hepatitis A (HAV) infection. Her 4-year-old child has already received all age-appropriate vaccines.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician in June for a follow-up examination after being diagnosed with HIV infection 3 months ago. He has been taking combined antiretroviral therapy since then. He feels well. He is sexually active with both female and male partners and regularly uses barrier protection. He does not smoke and drinks 2–3 glasses of wine on weekends. The patient did not receive any childhood vaccines besides the hepatitis B vaccine. Six years ago, he received the tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccination. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. His CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count is 190/mm3. Which of the following immunizations should be administered at this time?

choices.text: Tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vaccination against varicella requires the administration of a live attenuated vaccine. Live vaccines should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals such as this patient, who has a CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count < 200/mm3. Once his CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count is > 200/mm3, he should receive this vaccine to protect him against chickenpox and shingles.

B) INCORRECT:

The tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccination is indicated in adults who did not receive the usual schedule of vaccinations during childhood, as is the case in this patient. Booster vaccination with tetanus and diphtheria toxoids (Td) is required every 10 years in order to maintain full immunity. However, this patient received his Tdap vaccine only 6 years ago, which means that he will not require a booster dose of the Td vaccine for another 4 years.

C) INCORRECT:

Annual Influenza vaccination with the inactivated or recombinant vaccine is highly recommended, especially in immunocompromised individuals such as this patient. However, he is currently being seen in the month of June, which is still too early for the influenza vaccine. For maximum protection from the influenza virus, he should receive the vaccine at a follow-up visit in the early fall. The live-attenuated influenza vaccine should not be administered to individuals with HIV infection, regardless of their CD4+ T lymphocyte count.

D) INCORRECT:

Vaccination against measles, mumps, and rubella requires the administration of a live attenuated vaccine. Live attenuated vaccines should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals such as this patient, who has a CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count of < 200/mm3. Once his CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count is > 200/mm3, he should receive this vaccine.

E) INCORRECT:

Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk for infection, including with human papillomavirus (HPV). However, the same guidelines apply to immunocompromised individuals as the general population, which is that HPV vaccination is recommended in all individuals ≤ 26 years of age. While the FDA has approved the HPV vaccine for individuals up to 45 years of age, the decision to receive a vaccine after 26 years of age is established on an individual basis.

F) INCORRECT:

Pneumococcal polysaccharide 23 vaccine (PPSV23) is recommended for individuals aged 19–65 years who are immunocompromised (e.g., those with HIV). However, the PPSV23 vaccine should not be administered before the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, PCV15. Because this patient's vaccination history is unknown, he should receive the PCV15 now and return in at least 8 weeks to receive the PPSV23. Alternatively, individuals can be given one dose of the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine PCV20 without subsequent need for PPSV23.

G) CORRECT:

Patients with HIV infection or chronic liver disease are at increased risk of developing a severe disease following infection with the hepatitis A (HepA) virus. The HepA vaccine is part of the routine vaccine regimen and is recommended for all individuals between 12 and 23 months of age with a second dose administered at least 6 months later. Any adult who did not receive the vaccine and is at high risk for HepA infection or severe disease should be vaccinated. The HepA vaccine is a killed vaccine and can be safely administered even if the patient has a low CD4 T-cell count.

Risk factors for HepA infection include recent travel to an area where the virus is endemic, recreational drug use, and men who have sex with men.
questions.hint: Special attention should be paid to the selection of appropriate vaccinations in patients with HIV, especially those with a low CD4 count, which indicates severe immunodeficiency.

questions.text: Two weeks after returning from vacation in Mexico, a 21-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of malaise, nausea, vomiting, fever, and abdominal pain. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and right upper quadrant tenderness. The liver is palpated 1.5 cm below the right costal margin. A biopsy specimen of this patient's liver would most likely show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Ground glass hepatocytes and periportal inflammation
Necrosis with neutrophilic infiltrate and Mallory bodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The onion-skin appearance of concentric periductal fibrosis of small bile ducts is a histopathological finding specific to primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). PSC manifests with jaundice, hepatomegaly, and right upper quadrant pain, similar to what is seen in this patient; however, PSC is a chronic, progressive disorder whereas this patient's symptoms developed over two weeks.

B) INCORRECT:

Ground glass hepatocytes are pathognomonic for chronic hepatitis B infection, while periportal inflammation with a lymphocytic infiltrate is a nonspecific histopathological finding consistent with chronic hepatitides. Acute hepatitis B infection can manifest with flu-like symptoms, scleral icterus, and right upper quadrant pain, all of which are seen here. However, hepatitis B is transmitted sexually and parenterally, and this patient does not have any risk factors for acquiring such an infection, e.g., IV drug use or high-risk sexual behavior.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Most of the hepatocytes have a pale, homogeneous cytoplasm (ground glass hepatocytes; examples marked by blue overlay).

Ground glass hepatocytes are often found in chronic hepatitis B infection.

C) CORRECT:

Ballooning degeneration (swelling of hepatocytes due to depletion of ATP) and bridging necrosis (confluent necrosis spanning adjacent lobules) are histopathological findings seen in acute viral hepatitis. Other typical findings include Councilman bodies (reflecting shrunken hepatocytes that underwent apoptosis) and periportal infiltration with helper T cells, B cells, and plasma cells. While the virus has a minimally cytotoxic effect upon cells, the immunological response is the primary method of hepatocyte injury. Hepatitis A infection can manifest with acute symptoms or be asymptomatic, but it does not become chronic, unlike hepatitis B and hepatitis C infections.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a hepatic tissue sample (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

There is heavy necroinflammatory activity in this hepatic lobule. The hepatocytes show reactive changes, including prominent swelling (exemplary green outline). Several apoptotic hepatocytes (also known as “acidophilic bodies” or “Councilman bodies;” examples indicated by yellow outlines) are visible.

These findings are typical of inflammatory changes consistent with an acute viral hepatitis (in this case hepatitis B exacerbated by hepatitis E coinfection).

D) INCORRECT:

Necrosis with neutrophilic infiltrate and Mallory bodies is a histopathological finding that indicates alcohol-associated hepatitis. Patients with alcohol-associated hepatitis may present with nausea, icterus, fatigue, and hepatomegaly, all of which are seen here. However, alcohol-associated hepatitis typically manifests between 40–50 years of age in individuals with a history of daily, heavy alcohol use for more than 20 years, which is inconsistent with this patient's history.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (H&E stain; very high magnification)

An enlarged hepatocyte with cobweb-like cytoplasm, known as ballooning degeneration (example indicated by yellow overlay), can be seen. An intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion with a twisted rope appearance, known as a Mallory body (example indicated by blue overlay), is visible. Additionally, macrovesicular steatosis (examples indicated by arrowheads) can be seen in the surrounding hepatocytes.

Macrovesicular steatosis and mallory bodies are findings that indicate steatohepatitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Lymphocytic infiltration and progressive ductopenia are characteristic of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). Patients present with malaise, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and right upper quadrant pain, as seen here. However, PBC is a chronic, progressive disorder whereas this patient's symptoms developed over two weeks. Moreover, additional symptoms such as pruritus, maldigestion, and xanthomas would be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Piecemeal necrosis is characteristic of the degeneration of hepatocytes that occurs in chronic hepatitides such as hepatitis B and hepatitis C. Patients present with malaise, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and right upper quadrant pain, similar to what is seen here. However, this patient's symptoms developed over two weeks, and additional symptoms of chronic liver disease (e.g., spider angiomata, gynecomastia, easy bruising) would be expected. Moreover, this patient does not have any risk factors for acquiring these types of hepatitis infection, e.g., IV drug use or high-risk sexual behavior.
questions.hint: Acute onset of nausea, vomiting, fever, scleral icterus, right upper quadrant abdominal pain, and hepatomegaly following recent travel to Mexico are suggestive of acute hepatitis A infection.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the physician for a pre-employment examination. He recently traveled to Guatemala. He feels well but has not seen a physician in several years, and his immunization records are unavailable. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Anti-HAV IgM
Positive


Anti-HAV IgG
Negative


HBsAg
Negative


Anti-HBs
Positive


HBcAg
Negative


Anti-HBc
Negative


HBeAg
Negative


Anti-HBe
Negative


Anti-HCV
Negative


Which of the following best explains this patient's laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with active hepatitis B infection, serum studies for HBeAg and HBcAg would be positive. Either anti-HBc IgM (acute active infection) or anti-HBc IgG (chronic active infection) would also be positive. In addition, this patient tests positive for anti-HBs antibodies, which would prevent infection.
Image Description:

The main serological feature of active chronic HBV infection is the persistence of HBV DNA and the antigens HBsAg and HBeAg despite resolution of acute infection. Transaminase levels may be normal or increased and fluctuate between periods of active and inactive chronic infection. For inactive chronic HBV infection, Anti-HBe develops and HBeAg is no longer detectable.

B) CORRECT:

Active hepatitis A infection is confirmed in this patient by the presence of IgM antibodies against the hepatitis A virus (anti-HAV IgM antibodies) on serology. Anti-HAV IgM antibodies appear approx. 1 week after onset of infection and persist for 3–6 months. This patient is asymptomatic because his infection is very mild or because the disease is still in the incubation period, which lasts 2–6 weeks. Hepatitis A is more prevalent in developing countries (e.g., Guatemala).

Unlike hepatitis B and hepatitis C, hepatitis A does not have a carrier state. The presence of anti-HAV IgG antibodies on serology would indicate prior hepatitis A infection or immunization. This patient tests positive for anti-HBs antibodies and negative for anti-HBc antibodies, which indicates that he has been immunized against hepatitis B.
Image Description:

Anti-HAV IgM antibodies are detectable ∼ 5–10 days after infection (5–10 days before clinical symptoms develop), with peak levels ∼ 1 month after infection. Levels typically become undetectable within 3–6 months post infection. Assessing for the presence of anti-HAV IgM antibodies is the standard diagnostic test for active hepatitis A.

During HAV infection, anti-HAV IgG antibodies are typically detectable when clinical symptoms develop and subsequently persist indefinitely. They are also produced in response to vaccination and are a marker of immunity to reinfection.

HAV RNA can be detected in stool and serum samples in patients with hepatitis A. This test is not routinely used but can be helpful during outbreaks, as HAV RNA can be detected as early as the first week after infection.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with previous hepatitis B infection, serum studies for anti-HBs antibodies are positive, as in this case. However, anti-HBe antibodies and anti-HBc IgG antibodies would also be present. The presence of anti-HBs antibodies on serology in the absence of other hepatitis B markers indicates that this patient has been immunized against hepatitis B.
Image Description:

Schematic depiction of the time frames in which HBV DNA, antigens, and antibodies are measurable (and transaminases elevated) during acute HBV infection and resolution. Note that the timing can vary significantly between patients and that the pattern in chronic infection differs.

The window period is an interval in which HBsAg is no longer measurable, anti-HBs is not yet measurable, and only Anti-HBc and Anti-HBe can be detected.

HBV DNA: hepatitis B virus DNA; HBsAg: hepatitis B surface antigen; HBeAg: hepatitis B e antigen; Anti-HBc IgM: anti-hepatitis B core antigen IgM antibody; Anti-HBc total: anti-HBc IgM + anti-HBc IgG (conventionally measured together); Anti-HBs: anti-hepatitis B surface antigen antibody; Anti-HBe: anti-hepatitis Be antigen antibody

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with previous hepatitis A infection, serum studies for anti-HAV IgG antibodies would be positive. These antibodies appear about 1–2 weeks after infection and persist for life.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with chronic hepatitis B infection, serum studies for HBsAg, HBeAg, and anti-HBc IgG antibodies would be positive. In addition, this patient tests positive for anti-HBs antibodies, which would prevent infection.
Image Description:

The main serological feature of active chronic HBV infection is the persistence of HBV DNA and the antigens HBsAg and HBeAg despite resolution of acute infection. Transaminase levels may be normal or increased and fluctuate between periods of active and inactive chronic infection. For inactive chronic HBV infection, Anti-HBe develops and HBeAg is no longer detectable.

F) INCORRECT:

In patients with chronic hepatitis C infection, serum studies for anti-HCV antibodies would be positive.
Image Description:

HCV RNA is continuously detectable throughout chronic hepatitis C infection, with levels peaking at approx. 6 weeks and lower spikes occurring episodically thereafter. Transaminase levels follow the pattern of HCV RNA with a slight delay of approx. 1 week. Antibody production begins at 2 months after infection and plateaus at approx. 4 months, thus not corresponding to HCV RNA and transaminase levels.

G) INCORRECT:

In patients who have been vaccinated against hepatitis A, serum studies for anti-HAV IgG antibodies would be positive.

questions.text:
A healthy 19-year-old man will travel to India in 10 days for the birth of his niece. Review of the patient’s immunization history reveals that he has not been vaccinated against hepatitis A virus infection. He has lived in the United States his entire life.
Which one of the following approaches to preventing hepatitis A virus infection is most appropriate for this traveler?

choices.text: Administer a single dose of immunoglobulin the day before departure
Administer the first dose of hepatitis A vaccine now
Provide education on safe food practices without additional prophylaxis or testing
Administer the first dose of hepatitis A vaccine, and administer immunoglobulin the day before departure
Test for antibody titers now; if negative, administer the first dose of hepatitis A vaccine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inactivated hepatitis A vaccines are effective in preventing hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection in travelers to countries with endemic HAV. In a 2007 clinical trial, both hepatitis A vaccine and immunoglobulin were effective within 14 days after exposure to HAV infection. Current guidelines state that the vaccine is sufficient for healthy international travelers younger than age 40 regardless of the proximity of the imminent departure. Because the vaccine induces active immunity and conveys longer protection, it is preferred over immunoglobulin.

B) CORRECT:

Inactivated hepatitis A vaccines are effective in preventing hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection in travelers to countries with endemic HAV. In a 2007 clinical trial, both hepatitis A vaccine and immunoglobulin were effective within 14 days after exposure to HAV infection. Current guidelines state that the vaccine is sufficient for healthy international travelers younger than age 40 regardless of the proximity of the imminent departure.

This patient should receive the first dose of the HAV vaccine now. Because the vaccine induces active immunity and conveys longer protection, it is preferred over immunoglobulin. Coadministration of the vaccine with immunoglobulin may be considered for patients traveling within 2 weeks who are older than 40 years of age, are immunocompromised, or have chronic liver disease. A second vaccine dose should be administered 6 to 12 months after the first.

For those traveling in countries with high or intermediate endemic HAV, a combination vaccine against both HAV and hepatitis B virus may be administered on an accelerated schedule of three doses at 0, 7, and 21 to 30 days, followed by a booster dose at 12 months.

Key learning point: The most effective preventive strategy for patients traveling to a region with high or intermediate prevalence of hepatitis A virus infection is to administer the first dose of hepatitis A vaccine as soon as travel is considered.

C) INCORRECT:

Education about safe food practices is important but is not sufficient for protection against hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection. Travelers to HAV-endemic countries are at increased risk for HAV infection, as well as other foodborne infections, even if they report that they are careful about what they eat and drink.

D) INCORRECT:

Inactivated hepatitis A vaccines are effective in preventing hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection in travelers to countries with endemic HAV. In a 2007 clinical trial, both hepatitis A vaccine and immunoglobulin were effective within 14 days after exposure to HAV infection. Current guidelines state that the vaccine is sufficient for healthy international travelers younger than age 40 regardless of the proximity of the imminent departure. Coadministration of the vaccine with immunoglobulin may be considered for patients traveling within 2 weeks who are older than 40 years of age, are immunocompromised, or have chronic liver disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Pre-vaccination serologic testing is not recommended for people without risk factors for past hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection. Such risk factors include being born in or living in HAV endemic areas, using injection or non-injection illicit drugs, and engaging in male-to-male sex.

questions.text:
A healthy 16-year-old boy will travel to India with his family in 10 days for the birth of his niece. Review of the patient’s immunization history reveals that he has not been vaccinated against hepatitis A virus infection. He has lived in the U.S. his entire life.
Which one of the following approaches to preventing hepatitis A virus infection is most appropriate for this traveler?

choices.text: Test for antibody titers now; if negative, administer the first dose of hepatitis A vaccine
Provide education on safe food practices without additional prophylaxis or testing
Administer the first dose of hepatitis A vaccine, and administer immunoglobulin the day before departure
Administer the first dose of hepatitis A vaccine now
Administer a single dose of immunoglobulin the day before departure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prevaccination serologic testing is not recommended for people without risk factors for past HAV infection. Such risk factors include being born in or living in HAV endemic areas, using injection or non-injection illicit drugs, and engaging in male-to-male sex.

B) INCORRECT:

Education about safe food practices is important but is not sufficient for protection against HAV infection. Travelers to HAV-endemic countries are at increased risk for HAV infection, as well as other foodborne infections, even if they report that they are careful about what they eat and drink.

C) INCORRECT:

Coadministration of the vaccine with immunoglobulin may be considered for patients traveling within 2 weeks who are older adults, who are immunocompromised, or who have chronic liver disease.

D) CORRECT:

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) vaccine is recommended as a routine childhood immunization in a two-part series, with the first dose administered at 12 months of age and the second at 18 months. Individuals who did not receive the childhood vaccines and are planning to travel to an HAV-endemic area should receive the first dose of HAV vaccine as soon as the trip is considered, regardless of the proximity of the imminent departure. The second dose should then be administered 6 months later. If an infant between 6 and 12 months of age is traveling to a high-risk area, he or she should receive a dose of HAV vaccine before travel and then complete the series with two additional doses — the first at 12 months of age and the second 6 to 18 months later.

Previous guidelines called for coadministration of immunoglobulin if the traveler was departing within 2 weeks. However, the ACIP has amended its guidelines to recommend vaccine alone for most travelers, based on a 2007 clinical trial showing that the vaccine and immunoglobulin offered equivalent postexposure protection in healthy international travelers older than 40 years of age. The vaccine is preferred over immunoglobulin because it induces active immunity and conveys longer protection.

Coadministration of the vaccine with immunoglobulin may be considered for patients traveling within 2 weeks who are older adults, who are immunocompromised, or who have chronic liver disease.

Immunoglobulin alone is recommended for HAV preexposure prophylaxis in travelers younger than 6 months of age.

Key learning point: The most effective prevention strategy for an adolescent who has not been vaccinated against hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection and is traveling to a region with a high or intermediate prevalence of HAV infection is to administer the first dose of HAV vaccine as soon as travel is considered.

E) INCORRECT:

Previous guidelines called for coadministration of immunoglobulin if the traveler was departing within 2 weeks. However, the ACIP has amended its guidelines to recommend vaccine alone for most travelers, based on a 2007 clinical trial showing that the vaccine and immunoglobulin offered equivalent postexposure protection in healthy international travelers older than 40 years of age. The vaccine is preferred over immunoglobulin because it induces active immunity and conveys longer protection.

Immunoglobulin alone is recommended for HAV preexposure prophylaxis in travelers younger than 6 months of age.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His immunization records are unavailable. He works as a financial consultant and will go on a business trip to Mexico City in 6 weeks. Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malaria chemoprophylaxis consists of the preventive administration of certain drugs (e.g., atovaquone-proguanil, mefloquine). Currently, the risk of malaria for US travelers to Mexico is very low. Mexico City is considered malaria-free. Therefore, the CDC does not routinely recommend the use of antimalarial drugs for individuals traveling to Mexico except for travelers going to the very South or some states near the Pacific coast.

B) INCORRECT:

Vaccination against rabies is indicated after exposure with a presumably infected animal (e.g., dog, bat) or for individuals who are at high risk of exposure, which include veterinarians and laboratory workers working with the rabies virus. International travelers to countries where the disease is endemic or where there is a low availability of vaccines (e.g., countries in Africa, South America, Southeast Asia, remote locations) should also receive the vaccine. This patient is going on a business trip, so he will not be in any remote locations for a long period of time.

C) INCORRECT:

As of 2017, a live oral cholera vaccine has been approved by the FDA. Vaccination against vibrio cholerae is indicated in travelers going to countries in which cholera infections are reported regularly or where a cholera outbreak is occurring. Although there has been a cholera epidemic in Mexico in the past, the risk for this business traveler is very low as long as he follows simple preventative measures (water and food hygiene).

D) INCORRECT:

Immunization against yellow fever is recommended for international travelers ≥ 9 months of age who plan on visiting endemic regions in South America or Sub-Saharan Africa. Because the disease is not prevalent in Mexico, this recommendation does not apply to this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Areas with moderate to high prevalence of hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection include most parts of South America, Africa, Asia, Eastern Europe, Mexico, and Central America. Travelers to these areas should receive an HAV vaccine (ideally ≥ 2 weeks before traveling). Individuals who are due to travel to these areas in < 2 weeks require both an HAV vaccine and immune globulin, which should be injected at different anatomical sites at the same time. Because HAV is transmitted mainly via the consumption of food or water that has been contaminated with feces (e.g., shellfish), travelers should also be advised to follow primary preventive measures such as washing hands, boiling or chlorinating water, and avoiding raw food.

As of 2006, routine immunization against HAV is recommended for all children in the US older than 12 months.
questions.hint: Considering that this patient's immunization records are unavailable and he will soon travel to Mexico, he needs to be vaccinated against several common illnesses.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to the office for a pre-employment examination. He recently traveled to Guatemala. He feels well but has not seen a healthcare provider in several years, and his immunization records are unavailable. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Anti-HAV IgM
Positive


Anti-HAV IgG
Negative


HBsAg
Negative


Anti-HBs
Positive


HBcAg
Negative


Anti-HBc
Negative


HBeAg
Negative


Anti-HBe
Negative


Anti-HCV
Negative


Which of the following best explains this patient's laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with active hepatitis B infection, serum studies for HBeAg and HBcAg would be positive. Either anti-HBc IgM (acute active infection) or anti-HBc IgG (chronic active infection) would also be positive. In addition, this patient tests positive for anti-HBs antibodies, which would prevent infection.
Image Description:

The main serological feature of active chronic HBV infection is the persistence of HBV DNA and the antigens HBsAg and HBeAg despite resolution of acute infection. Transaminase levels may be normal or increased and fluctuate between periods of active and inactive chronic infection. For inactive chronic HBV infection, Anti-HBe develops and HBeAg is no longer detectable.

B) CORRECT:

Active hepatitis A infection is confirmed in this patient by the presence of IgM antibodies against the hepatitis A virus (anti-HAV IgM antibodies) on serology. Anti-HAV IgM antibodies appear approx. 1 week after onset of infection and persist for 3–6 months. This patient is asymptomatic because his infection is very mild or because the disease is still in the incubation period, which lasts 2–6 weeks. Hepatitis A is more prevalent in developing countries (e.g., Guatemala).

Unlike hepatitis B and hepatitis C, hepatitis A does not have a carrier state. The presence of anti-HAV IgG antibodies on serology would indicate prior hepatitis A infection or immunization. This patient tests positive for anti-HBs antibodies and negative for anti-HBc antibodies, which indicates that he has been immunized against hepatitis B.

Key learning point: The presence of anti-HAV IgM without anti-HAV IgG indicates an active hepatitis A infection, while anti-HAV IgG alone suggests past infection or immunization.
Image Description:

Anti-HAV IgM antibodies are detectable ∼ 5–10 days after infection (5–10 days before clinical symptoms develop), with peak levels ∼ 1 month after infection. Levels typically become undetectable within 3–6 months post infection. Assessing for the presence of anti-HAV IgM antibodies is the standard diagnostic test for active hepatitis A.

During HAV infection, anti-HAV IgG antibodies are typically detectable when clinical symptoms develop and subsequently persist indefinitely. They are also produced in response to vaccination and are a marker of immunity to reinfection.

HAV RNA can be detected in stool and serum samples in patients with hepatitis A. This test is not routinely used but can be helpful during outbreaks, as HAV RNA can be detected as early as the first week after infection.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with previous hepatitis B infection, serum studies for anti-HBs antibodies are positive, as in this case. However, anti-HBe antibodies and anti-HBc IgG antibodies would also be present. The presence of anti-HBs antibodies on serology in the absence of other hepatitis B markers indicates that this patient has been immunized against hepatitis B.
Image Description:

Schematic depiction of the time frames in which HBV DNA, antigens, and antibodies are measurable (and transaminases elevated) during acute HBV infection and resolution. Note that the timing can vary significantly between patients and that the pattern in chronic infection differs.

The window period is an interval in which HBsAg is no longer measurable, anti-HBs is not yet measurable, and only Anti-HBc and Anti-HBe can be detected.

HBV DNA: hepatitis B virus DNA; HBsAg: hepatitis B surface antigen; HBeAg: hepatitis B e antigen; Anti-HBc IgM: anti-hepatitis B core antigen IgM antibody; Anti-HBc total: anti-HBc IgM + anti-HBc IgG (conventionally measured together); Anti-HBs: anti-hepatitis B surface antigen antibody; Anti-HBe: anti-hepatitis Be antigen antibody

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with previous hepatitis A infection, serum studies for anti-HAV IgG antibodies would be positive. These antibodies appear about 1–2 weeks after infection and persist for life.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients who have been vaccinated against hepatitis A, serum studies for anti-HAV IgG antibodies would be positive.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents with a 5-day history of low-grade fever, malaise, and abdominal discomfort. Over the past two days, he has noticed dark urine and yellowish discoloration of the sclera. He recently returned from a week-long summer camp where group meals were shared. Examination shows mild right upper quadrant tenderness.

Temperature
38.0 °C

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hepatitis typically presents subacutely or chronically, often in adolescent females or adults. The acute symptom onset and recent group meal exposure do not fit the typical presentation. Additionally, specific autoantibodies are usually involved, which are not mentioned here.

B) CORRECT:

Hepatitis A manifests with low-grade fever, malaise, abdominal discomfort, dark urine, and jaundice. It is transmitted via the fecal-oral route, often through contaminated food or water, as suggested by the shared meals at summer camp. Hepatitis A virus is an RNA picornavirus causing acute, self-limited infection without chronic progression. Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting anti-hepatitis A virus IgM antibodies. The clinical presentation and epidemiological context align with hepatitis A infection in this patient.

Key learning point: In children, hepatitis A is the most common cause of acute viral hepatitis, presenting with symptoms such as fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice, and is transmitted via the fecal-oral route.

C) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis C is primarily transmitted via blood-to-blood contact, not through contaminated food or water. Acute symptoms are uncommon in children, and the incubation period is longer. The patient's exposure history and symptom onset do not align with hepatitis C infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B is transmitted through blood and bodily fluids, not typically through shared meals. In children, it often leads to asymptomatic or chronic infection rather than acute symptoms. The transmission route and acute presentation in this patient do not support hepatitis B as the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man presents with a five-day history of progressive fatigue and yellow discoloration of his sclera to the Outpatient Clinic. He reports mild right upper quadrant discomfort but no changes in bowel habits. He briefly traveled to a rural region three weeks ago. On examination, he appears jaundiced (see lab results).

Temperature
37.8°C



Test
Result
Normal Values



Total bilirubin
86 μmol/L
3.5 - 16.5 μmol/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
920 IU/L
12 - 40 IU/L


Alanine aminotransferase
1100 IU/L
5 - 40 IU/L


Alkaline phosphatase
150 IU/L
39 - 117 IU/L



What is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute viral hepatitis manifests with hepatocellular injury and impaired bilirubin processing, leading to symptoms such as jaundice, fatigue, and right upper quadrant discomfort. The laboratory findings of markedly elevated transaminases (AST and ALT) indicate significant hepatocellular damage, with ALT often more elevated in viral hepatitis. The increased total bilirubin supports impaired hepatic function. The patient's recent travel to a rural area suggests potential exposure to hepatitis viruses, commonly transmitted via the fecal–oral route, aligning with an acute infectious hepatitis process.

Key learning point: Infective hepatitis is characterized by elevated liver enzymes (ALT and AST) and bilirubin levels, along with symptoms like jaundice and abdominal pain, distinguishing it from other causes of jaundice.

B) INCORRECT:

Obstructive choledocholithiasis typically presents with jaundice and right upper quadrant pain, but the laboratory pattern shows a disproportionate elevation of alkaline phosphatase relative to transaminases. In this patient, the transaminases are markedly elevated, indicating hepatocellular injury rather than cholestasis. Additionally, the mild discomfort and lack of symptoms like pruritus or cholangitis do not support biliary obstruction.

C) INCORRECT:

Dubin-Johnson syndrome causes chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with minimal liver enzyme elevation. The marked transaminase elevations in this patient indicate acute hepatocellular injury, inconsistent with Dubin-Johnson syndrome's benign enzyme profile. The acute symptoms and travel history suggest an inflammatory process, not a chronic pigment deposition disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic anemia causes jaundice due to increased unconjugated bilirubin from red blood cell destruction. However, it does not cause significant transaminase elevation, as seen here. Instead, hemolysis typically shows elevated lactate dehydrogenase, decreased haptoglobin, and increased reticulocytes. The elevated liver enzymes and travel history suggest a hepatocellular process, not hemolysis.

questions.text:
You are seeing a 32-year-old man in your clinic for a pre-employment examination. He recently traveled to Guatemala. He reports feeling well and has not seen a healthcare provider in several years. His immunization records are unavailable. Physical examination is normal. Serum studies show:


Anti-HAV IgM
Positive


Anti-HAV IgG
Negative


HBsAg
Negative


Anti-HBs
Positive


HBcAg
Negative


Anti-HBc
Negative


HBeAg
Negative


Anti-HBe
Negative


Anti-HCV
Negative


Which one of the following best explains these laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Active hepatitis A infection is confirmed in this patient by the presence of IgM antibodies against the hepatitis A virus (anti-HAV IgM antibodies) on serology. Anti-HAV IgM antibodies appear approx. 1 week after onset of infection and persist for 3–6 months. This patient is asymptomatic because his infection is very mild or because the disease is still in the incubation period, which lasts 2–6 weeks. Hepatitis A is more prevalent in developing countries (e.g., Guatemala).

Unlike hepatitis B and hepatitis C, hepatitis A does not have a carrier state. The presence of anti-HAV IgG antibodies on serology would indicate prior hepatitis A infection or immunization. This patient tests positive for anti-HBs antibodies and negative for anti-HBc antibodies, which indicates that he has been immunized against hepatitis B.

Key learning point: The presence of anti-HAV IgM without anti-HAV IgG indicates an active hepatitis A infection, while anti-HAV IgG would indicate prior infection or vaccination.
Image Description:

Anti-HAV IgM antibodies are detectable ∼ 5–10 days after infection (5–10 days before clinical symptoms develop), with peak levels ∼ 1 month after infection. Levels typically become undetectable within 3–6 months post infection. Assessing for the presence of anti-HAV IgM antibodies is the standard diagnostic test for active hepatitis A.

During HAV infection, anti-HAV IgG antibodies are typically detectable when clinical symptoms develop and subsequently persist indefinitely. They are also produced in response to vaccination and are a marker of immunity to reinfection.

HAV RNA can be detected in stool and serum samples in patients with hepatitis A. This test is not routinely used but can be helpful during outbreaks, as HAV RNA can be detected as early as the first week after infection.

B) INCORRECT:

In patients with previous hepatitis B infection, serum studies for anti-HBs antibodies are positive, as in this case. However, anti-HBe antibodies and anti-HBc IgG antibodies would also be present. The presence of anti-HBs antibodies on serology in the absence of other hepatitis B markers indicates that this patient has been immunized against hepatitis B.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with active hepatitis B infection, serum studies for HBeAg and HBcAg would be positive. Either anti-HBc IgM (acute active infection) or anti-HBc IgG (chronic active infection) would also be positive. In addition, this patient tests positive for anti-HBs antibodies, which would prevent infection.

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with previous hepatitis A infection, serum studies for anti-HAV IgG antibodies would be positive. These antibodies appear about 1–2 weeks after infection and persist for life.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients who have been vaccinated against hepatitis A, serum studies for anti-HAV IgG antibodies would be positive.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman comes to your clinic for follow-up to discuss her laboratory test results. Three days ago, she presented with right upper abdominal pain, anorexia, and nausea. On examination today, she has scleral icterus, excoriation marks over the extremities, and tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory studies show:


Bilirubin, total, blood
58 μmol/L (3–17)


Alkaline phosphatase, blood
181 IU/L (50–136)


Alanine aminotransferase (ALT), blood
723 IU/L (17–63)


Aspartate aminotransferase (AST), blood
385 IU/L (15–37)


Hepatitis A IgM antibody, blood
Positive


Hepatitis A IgG antibody, blood
Negative


Hepatitis B surface antibodies, blood
Positive


Hepatitis B surface antigen, blood
Negative


Hepatitis B core IgM antibody, blood
Negative


Hepatitis C antibody, blood
Negative


This patient's history is most likely to reveal which one of the following?

choices.text: Recent visit to an acupuncture center.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The hepatitis A virus (HAV) is transmitted via the fecal-oral route, typically by the consumption of undercooked foods, such as raw mussels. Shellfish can concentrate the virus from seawater contaminated with human sewage. In the US, about half of cases of hepatitis A infection are acquired during visits to countries where HAV is endemic (especially tropical or subtropical regions). Hepatitis A infection is self-limiting, and patients do not become carriers or develop chronic hepatitis. Thus, supportive care is usually the only treatment required.

Routine immunization against hepatitis A virus is recommended for all children older than 12 months of age, travelers to foreign countries where HAV is endemic, men who have sex with men, and patients with chronic liver disease.

Key learning point: Hepatitis A is typically transmitted via the fecal-oral route, most commonly through consumption of contaminated food such as undercooked shellfish.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute hepatitis B infection can manifest with nausea, jaundice, right upper abdominal pain, hyperbilirubinemia, and increased serum transaminase concentrations. However, this patient's laboratory tests are inconsistent with this diagnosis (negative HBsAg and anti-HBc IgM antibody); in contrast, they confirm immunity against HBV due to vaccination (positive anti-HBs antibody).

C) INCORRECT:

Infection with hepatitis B and hepatitis C viruses transmitted via contaminated instruments and shared needles (e.g., in acupuncture centers) can cause acute hepatitis. However, this patient's laboratory tests are inconsistent with both HBV (negative HBsAg and anti-HBc IgM antibody) and HCV (negative HCV antibody) infection. Hepatitis A is very rarely transmitted by blood.

D) INCORRECT:

Infection with hepatitis A virus (HAV) due to contamination of freshwater lakes is unlikely in developed countries, as treatment processes and dilution within municipal water systems render HAV noninfectious, and disease outbreaks due to flooding-related sewage contamination of potable water sources have not occurred in the US in several decades. However, transmission of HAV via contaminated small private or community wells or swimming pools have been reported.

E) INCORRECT:

Infection with hepatitis B and hepatitis C viruses transmitted during unprotected sexual intercourse can cause acute hepatitis. However, this patient's laboratory tests are inconsistent with both HBV (negative HBsAg and anti-HBc IgM antibody) and HCV (negative HCV antibody) infection. Hepatitis A is rarely transmitted sexually.
questions.hint: The presence of hepatitis A IgM antibodies in this patient with scleral icterus, excoriation (indicating pruritus), and right upper quadrant tenderness confirms a diagnosis of acute hepatitis A infection.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. He has no history of serious illness and does not take any medications. His immunization records are unavailable. He works as a financial consultant and is planning a business trip to Mexico City in 6 weeks. Which one of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vaccination against rabies is indicated after exposure with a presumably infected animal (e.g., dog, bat) or for individuals who are at high risk of exposure, which include veterinarians and laboratory workers working with the rabies virus. International travelers to countries where the disease is endemic or where there is a low availability of vaccines (e.g., countries in Africa, South America, Southeast Asia, remote locations) should also receive the vaccine. This patient is going on a business trip, so he will not be in any remote locations for a long period of time.

B) INCORRECT:

Immunization against yellow fever is recommended for international travelers ≥ 9 months of age who plan on visiting endemic regions in South America or Sub-Saharan Africa. Because the disease is not prevalent in North American countries such as Mexico, this recommendation does not apply to this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Malaria chemoprophylaxis consists of the preventive administration of certain drugs (e.g., atovaquone-proguanil, mefloquine). Currently, the risk of malaria for travelers to major resort areas and urban centers in Mexico, including Mexico City, is very low. Therefore, the Committee to Advise on Tropical Medicine and Travel does not routinely recommend the use of antimalarial drugs for individuals traveling to Mexico except for travelers going to the very south of Mexico or some states near the Pacific coast.

D) CORRECT:

Areas with moderate to high prevalence of hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection include most parts of South America, Africa, Asia, Eastern Europe, Mexico, and Central America. Travelers to these areas should receive the HAV vaccine, which can be administered up to the day before departure. In individuals for whom the HAV vaccine is contraindicated (e.g., immunocompromised persons), human immunoglobulin can be used as an alternative. Because HAV is transmitted mainly via the consumption of food or water that has been contaminated with feces (e.g., shellfish), travelers should also be advised to follow primary preventive measures such as washing hands, boiling or chlorinating water, and avoiding raw food.

Key learning point: Travelers to areas with moderate to high hepatitis A prevalence should receive the hepatitis A vaccine.

E) INCORRECT:

Vaccination against cholera offers limited benefit and is not routinely recommended for most travelers. Moreover, no outbreaks of cholera have been reported in Mexico since 2014, and the risk for this business traveler is very low as long as he follows simple preventative measures (water and food hygiene).
questions.hint: Considering that this patient's immunization records are unavailable and he will soon travel to Mexico, he needs to be vaccinated against several common illnesses.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of jaundice. He reports having had right upper quadrant pain, fever, and malaise for the past week. He traveled to Thailand a few weeks ago, where he ate raw shellfish. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and hepatomegaly. Laboratory studies show AST 2000 U/L,  ALT 2200, and total bilirubin 6.2 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – The patient's recent travel to a hepatitis A endemic region with consumption of raw shellfish are classic risk factors for fecal-oral transmission of hepatitis A. The clinical course follows the typical pattern of hepatitis A: an initial prodromal phase with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and malaise, followed by the icteric phase with jaundice. The markedly elevated transaminases and elevated total bilirubin are typical laboratory findings in acute hepatitis A.

B) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B is transmitted through parenteral, sexual, or vertical routes rather than contaminated food or water. Hepatitis B is not typically transmitted via contaminated food.

C) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis C is transmitted primarily through parenteral routes such as needle sharing, blood transfusions, and needlestick injuries, not through contaminated food or water.

D) INCORRECT:

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is transmitted through saliva and respiratory secretions rather than contaminated food or water. While EBV can cause hepatitis, the consumption of raw shellfish is not a typical exposure route for EBV infection.

E) INCORRECT:

While cytomegalovirus (CMV) can cause hepatitis in immunocompromised patients, it manifests with mild transaminitis rather than the markedly elevated transaminases seen in this patient. Furthermore, the consumption of raw shellfish is not a typical exposure route for CMV.

questions.text: A 21-year-old college student presents to the clinic with a one-week history of fatigue, nausea, and low-grade fever. For the past two days, he has noticed his urine is darker and his eyes appear yellow. He recently returned from a spring break trip to Mexico where he ate at several local food stalls. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). Physical examination shows scleral icterus and right upper quadrant tenderness with hepatomegaly. Initial laboratory studies show an ALT of 1500 U/L, an AST of 950 U/L, and a total bilirubin of 4.5 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation of acute hepatitis, including a prodrome of constitutional symptoms followed by jaundice, is highly suggestive of a viral cause. The history of recent travel to an endemic area and eating at food stalls suggests a fecal-oral route of transmission, making hepatitis A virus (HAV) the most likely cause. The definitive diagnosis of acute HAV infection is made by detecting serum IgM antibodies to HAV (anti-HAV IgM). These antibodies become detectable 5–10 days before the onset of symptoms and typically persist for up to six months. Treatment for acute hepatitis A is supportive, as the infection is self-limiting and does not lead to a chronic state.

B) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B surface antigen is the primary marker for an active Hepatitis B infection. Although Hepatitis B can cause acute hepatitis, its primary modes of transmission are parenteral, sexual, and perinatal. This patient's risk factors, specifically recent travel and potentially contaminated food, are not typical for Hepatitis B virus acquisition.

C) INCORRECT:

While detecting hepatitis A virus RNA via PCR would confirm an active infection, it is not typically performed in routine practice. RNA testing is typically reserved for atypical cases or research purposes because another diagnostic study is more commonly used.

D) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is a cause of acute hepatitis, although it is more commonly associated with chronic infection and is often asymptomatic in the acute phase. The primary mode of transmission is parenteral, such as through IV drug use or contaminated blood products. This patient's history does not suggest a risk for HCV infection.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of IgG antibodies to hepatitis A virus indicates either a past infection that has resolved or immunity from vaccination. These antibodies persist for life, conferring long-term immunity. This test would not be useful for diagnosing this patient's current acute illness.
questions.hint: This patient's recent travel and consumption of street food suggest a fecal-oral route of transmission for his acute hepatitis.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up examination to learn about the results of her laboratory tests. Three days ago, she presented with right upper abdominal pain, anorexia, and nausea. Today, physical examination shows scleral icterus and excoriation marks over the extremities. There is tenderness to palpation at the right upper quadrant. Laboratory studies show:


Total bilirubin
3.4 mg/dL


Alkaline phosphatase
181 U/L


Alanine aminotransferase
723 U/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
385 U/L


Hepatitis A IgM antibody
positive


Hepatitis A IgG antibody
negative


Hepatitis B surface antibody
positive


Hepatitis B surface antigen
negative


Hepatitis B core IgM antibody
negative


Hepatitis C antibody
negative


This patient's history is most likely to reveal which of the following?

A) INCORRECT:

Infection with hepatitis A virus (HAV) due to contamination of freshwater lakes is unlikely in developed countries, as treatment processes and dilution within municipal water systems render HAV noninfectious, and disease outbreaks due to flooding-related sewage contamination of potable water sources have not occurred in the US in several decades. Infection with hepatitis B and hepatitis C viruses transmitted during unprotected sexual intercourse can cause acute hepatitis. However, this patient's laboratory tests are inconsistent with both HBV (negative HBsAg and anti-HBc IgM antibody) and HCV (negative HCV antibody) infection. Hepatitis A is rarely transmitted sexually.
